area_name: j. Friends in High Places Area

content.description: This route has the same start location as ‘Friends in High Places’. Start on the steep slab toward the left-facing arete. Climb left across the upper part of the slab and over several bulges to reach another overgrown arete. Join up with ‘Friends in High Places’ for the finish. Another cool Mike Steele first ascent.

This route starts 10 feet right of ‘The Rib’. 

Pitch 1: Start on the lower slab and up to the overhangs. Staying right of the upper arete, continue climbing up to a ledge with a tree on it. Belay here. 

Pitch 2: Exit belay ledge to the left around an arete and climb the face to a bolt. Continue climbing the steep face into horizontal off-width cracks. Traverse to the right and climb up past another bolt and into a dihedral under a roof. Pull the roof on the right climb up past the crux to the top. 

 Mark Ronca placed these bolts during the first ascent in the 90’s.
content.protection: Small to medium cams, 2 large cams, set of stoppers, small tri-cams, 2 quickdraws.
content.location: Start 10 feet right of 'The Rib' and just left of 'a groove in the slab.

content.description: Going by the route name, apparently Matt Hill and Mark Ronca were feeling like superstars during their first ascent of this route in the 90’s. This is a fun variation of a route but I separated it for FA purposes. This route starts toward the top of ‘Friends in High Places’. It has been called “The Dangler” of the Gap. Traverse right along the upper roof. Toward the edge of the roof, climb right and up the slab to the top.
content.protection: Standard gap rack: Small to medium cams, 1 large cam, set of stoppers, small tri-cams.

content.description:
With intensive cleaning or more traffic this could be a worthwile route, thought it is currently overgrown with small trees, poison ivy, and loose rock.  Hit it in the early spring before the foliage comes in. 

  Starting on the slab next to the open book that begins the rib, move up a groove to a small roof atop the slab.  Pull this on the right end, then pull up the larger roof at the middle on obvious jugs (well protected, but last decent gear for a bit).  Continue up until you reach a grassy ledge.  Belay on 1-1/2" gear at the left end of the ledge. 

  P2 - Climb up the corner above the belay, then head hard right, fighting Poison Ivy and a birch tree, then move up onto the soft sloping dirt ledge (Loose rocks!), and weave thru the small trees to 20' of gorgeous crack (reminiscent of CCK at the Gunks) At the end of the crack, move left, avoiding a stack of loose-looking blocks and a tree, then up to the top.  Belay on small gear or trees. 

  Descend via The Rib with 2 single rope rappels or 1 double rope rappel. 

  Rope drag on P2 could be pretty bad with the way the route wanders.  For an alternative, Continue P1 straight up from the belay ledge (looks unprotected), and do a semi-hanging belay below P2.
content.protection: Extra active gear in the 1-2" size is helpful for the route as described - At the P1 belay there aren't many other options.  A 4" piece is useful but not req'd.  Also used a 00 to protect the runout above the overhang, but it was pretty sketchy.
content.location: Right of The Open Book of the rib is a short slab, some tiered overhangs of blocky rock, and a prow/buttress.  The route climbs the slab, thru the overhangs, and belays under the prow, then continues up the face and inside corner right of the prow.

content.description: Start on the small ledge and climb up the left-facing dihedral crack about 15 to 20 feet until you reach a notch/small chimney with a ledge above it. Climb to ledge and walk-off. This route is sometimes done as a first pitch variation to ‘That Was Zen, This is Tao’.
content.location: This route starts 60 feet right of ‘The Rib’ between two large trees.

pathTokens: j. Friends in High Places Area

content.description: Another popular wall at the Gap. Usually overgrown with brush in the summer, so Spring and Fall climbing are the best.
